headline: Slow Cooker Beef Pot Roast
description: This beef pot roast is Chef John's recipe for seared beef simmered with vegetables and herbs in a slow cooker until incredibly tender and flavorful.

video.description: Come home to a delicious slow-cooked pot roast dinner.
video.name: Slow Cooker Beef Pot Roast

name: Slow Cooker Beef Pot Roast
recipeIngredient: 2.5 tablespoons all-purpose flour, divided, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Generously season both sides of roast with salt and pepper. Sprinkle top of roast with 1 tablespoon flour and pat onto meat. Shake off excess.
Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Sear roast until well-browned, 5 to 6 minutes per side. Remove roast from the skillet and set aside.

Reduce heat to medium. Melt butter in the skillet; cook and stir mushrooms in butter until tender, 3 to 4 minutes. Stir in onion; cook until onions are translucent and brown, about 5 minutes. Add garlic; stir until fragrant, about 1 minute.

Stir in remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons flour; cook and stir for about 1 minute. Add tomato paste and cook for another minute. Slowly add chicken broth while stirring; return to a simmer. Remove the skillet from heat.
Place carrots and celery in the slow cooker. Place roast over vegetables and pour in any accumulated juices. Add thyme and rosemary. Pour onion and mushroom mixture over the top of roast.
Cover and cook on High for 5 to 6 hours.
Skim off any fat from surface and remove bones. Season with salt and pepper.

review.reviewBody: I've made a ton of Chef John recipes and usually love them all. I make this just as written and it was pretty good but was a little bland for my taste. If I made it again I would definitely add some chopped potatoes to it. Also, every reheated bowl that I've made, I add some *black pepper and cayenne* and I think it brings the dish to 5 stars. Next time I make this, I'll add both to the chicken broth mixture on the front side.

This was absolutely delicious. I used a 3 pound boneless chuck roast. I also added a few quartered potatoes and I didn't have any tomato paste on hand, so I used 3 tbsp of pureed tomato. The thyme and rosemary were subtle and awesome and the roast was fork tender. Another good thing about this recipe is that I had almost all the ingredients at home and everything was reasonably priced. I have plenty of leftovers for tomorrow and I'm looking forward to them.

Absolutely wonderful. Braising the meat is key. Made this dish with what I had available at the time: vegetable broth, onions, yellow potatoes, dry thyme leaves and dry rosemary leaves, sea salt, pepper. Braising the meat as described is the key to a tender, tasty roast. Put yellow potatoes, halved in the bottom of the crock pot. Really enjoying this meal.

My husband and I can not get enough of this roast recipe! The flavors are fantastic! We subbed in beef broth instead of chicken, added extra celery (one extra stalk), dashed in extra thyme and rosemary (5/6 shakes from lid sifter). This is a keeper!

Made as directed using 2 1/2 lb boneless chuck roast with same amounts of other ingredients. Nice amount of gravy this way. Added Lots of fresh mushrooms, onions, and many more carrots. Used 1/2 T of dry thyme, and tsp of dry rosemary( instead of fresh).I didn't have potatoes but will def add next time. Delish
It was absolutely delicious.
Easy and delicious

Honestly, this was disappointing. I chose this Pot Roast recipe because it was Chef Johns - his recipes are typically spot on. The major problem was that it was pretty blah, it needed a lot more seasoning and I made it EXACTLY as written. I will make it again, but will add more seasonings - maybe red wine or Worcester sauce. Also, next time I won't put the carrots and celery under the beef - my meat was thicker than in Chef Johns video and I think it needed to have more contact with the chicken broth, onions etc. I don't think the mushrooms added anything. On the plus side, I learned that the carrots were perfectly cooked after 4 hours.
Just added some peas and corn
perfect! Had to do it slow cooking in a cast iron pot in the oven ( my crockpot broke down) but followed the exact recipe, and was so good!

I thought I'd left a review YEARS ago. I have followed this recipe for about over a decade now & my husband swears it's the best, over his mother's, grandmother's & neighbors! I've tried it with & without beef broth & honestly the chicken broth is better. I've added herbs at the beginning & at the end, the same with little potatoes, and now I just throw it all in in the beginning. I taste the herbs just fine & the little potatoes are cooked wonderfully, absorbing ask the yummy flavors! I've used a 7-bone roast & a regular chuck roast since it's getting harder to find the center cut (7-bone) kind. They're both delicious, but I really do prefer the bone-in. I like to think of the added goodness the bone offers the broth. I love spices so I always add in so much more bc that's just how I am. Sometimes, if I have it, I'll add a little red wine right after sautéing the tomatoe paste in the middle & it helps it mix all together. You can not go wrong with this recipe guys! Add what you will, take out what you don't like. This is hands down the BEST slow cooker pot recipe out there! I bought an instant pot & I have a Dutch oven, I've made pot roast in both & still prefer the old slow cooker. In the past I've made a cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce but my husband prefers me not to because he loves soaking it all up with soft rolls. Way to go Chef John, for always showing us the ART of cooking well! ♡♡
Perfect recipe, every time!
Sooooo good! Followed the exact recipe and it turned out great! It's an easy slow cooker recipe.
l loved it and so did my wife. My first roast. l will make it again. So good.
O…M….G I followed this exact recipe, but I used moose meat. This is now a staple in my house and I get asked, when I’m making this next.

Amazing! To “taste” the fresh herbs, I added more halfway through cooking. While I cooked for 6 hours, next time, will cook for 8+. Loved this recipe and will absolutely make again!! Thanks for another winner Chef John!
Yum! Yum! Yum! I love Chef John recipes and this one did not disappoint. I've made this recipe a few times now and everyone in my family loves it! Thanks Chef John!
Recipe was great and the roast beef tasted wonderful. I made it just the way it was and I wouldn't change anything.
Used a 3.5 lb grass-fed chuck roast, didn't have celery so added potatoes instead, turned out wonderfully!

I made this for Thanksgiving and the only thing I changed was the chicken broth for bone broth. This was a real hit with the family, my niece who is all about the turkey, said the roast was the best thing although everything else came out delicious as well. This will be my go to recipe for a roast from now on. It was so so good!

I love a good pot roast so I am constantly searching for the holy grail recipe for one. This one is IT! I made it two weeks ago and it was A M A Z I N G. I did do two things different. I added a can of beef consume' along with the chicken stock and I omitted the fresh herbs, simply because I forgot to get them at the market. As my luck would have it, my crock pot stopped working an hour into my cook. I placed everything into my Dutch oven and baked it low and slow. 250 degrees for about five hours. The extra consume' that I added turned into a delicious gravy that was served over some mashed red potatoes. I am having dinner guests tonight and guess what is on the menu? Yep and I can not wait! Enjoy everyone!
So good! 4 lb top round roast, 8 hors in crockpot.

I made this exactly like the recipe and it was delicious. My husband loved it! I wouldn't change a thing, other than my hubby likes carrots and said I did not put in enough, so I'd probably double up on carrots.
I subbed 2 2.5 pound+/- roasts and reduced to total cooking time to 4 hours on High. This recipe was hailed as a "keeper".

This was pretty good, typical pot roast, and all didn't go as planned....Instant Pot refused to do slow cook, so after using saute setting to braise meat and get onions cooking, put it all together and it just sat hot but not cooking, so eventually we did it on pressure cook and it was fine. Had no tomato paste, so used a squirt of ketchup, really couldn't tell it was there.

This is hands down the best pot roast I’ve ever made, however I did make a few minor alterations. First, I used a Dutch oven to make this a one pot recipe instead of a slow cooker. I cooked in the oven at about 200 for about 5 hours. I added LOTS of salt, pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder. I also added bay leaves and red wine. When the roast was done, I pulled the meat out of the Dutch oven and simmered the vegetables and gravy until it was the thickness I wanted and then added the meat back in. You can add a flour slurry to quicken this process. I also misread the directions and added the full can of tomato paste but it didn’t seem to effect the result. TASTE AS YOU GO and season accordingly, and if you do it in the oven, add a little extra chicken/beef broth. This is NOT a throw it together and leave it kind of recipe, as prep work and the cooking process before I put it in the oven took around an hour, HOWEVER it’s totally worth it to make the extra time to do it.
This was a family favorite. We loved it. Definitely using this recipe every time! Yummy!
Excellent! Didn’t use tomatoes paste and doubled the garlic!

Loved it! I do like potatoes in my pot roast so I added some quartered red new potatoes from the start and when I had about an hour or so left I put in some fresh green beans. I like my green beans a little as dente.....I also mixed up some flour and water and thickened the "gravy" at the end.

Made this this yesterday and followed recipe exactly. Pot roast is one of my favorites. First time I've ever used the "7 bone roast" and when available will be the piece of meat I'll be using (normally use chuck). I believe the bone in this roast really adds to the flavor. I'd say change nothing. Watch your cooking time, really depends on roast size. Mine was about 3 pounds, cooked little over 5 hrs.

First of all, don’t listen to the reviewers who say “this is too much work” or “you can just throw it all in the slow cooker without the prep.” I mean yes, it’s a little prep work, but it’s all recommended for a reason; to make this amazing versus just average. And if you take the extra 15 - 20 minutes, it’s worth it and scrumptious. Watch the video. I always watch Chef John’s videos because they are very educational, even for us experienced cooks. You literally do not have to change a thing with this recipe. The only modifications I made was I added a little red wine to deglaze the pan, and used a Montreal Steak seasoning. This is by far the BEST slow cooker pot roast recipe out there so don’t cut corners, do the prep as recommended and you won’t be disappointed! Thanks Chef John!
You never go wrong with a Chef John recipe. I had trouble finding a 7 bone roast in my local grocery store but found an equivalent cut of meat. The dish was so yummy!

The best pot roast I have ever made! Please follow directions to brown the roast well, then cook the mushrooms and onions for a while. It really gives it great depth of flavor. I did add about 1/4 cup of Merlot I had left in the fridge. There is more prep than most pot roasts where you dump in a can of soup or packet of dressing but is well worth it.
Halved the mushrooms and added potatoes
It came out awesome. We stuffed ourselves that night. Very good for leftovers.
This is the second time I make this recipe, it is delicious and our family’s favorite.

This recipe knocked my socks off. Absolutely fantastic. Hubby raved about it. It was a little extra effort to sauté the vegetables and sear the meat, but a worthwhile step. I didn’t add mushrooms (though I’m sure the would have been a delicious addition) and I added potatoes and once cup of red wine. Just fantastic!
It was very tender.

Not my favorite, I must admit. The pioneer woman has an easier and more delicious recipe on food networks site. I’m a little disappointed, I followed everything exactly as it says but it was quite bland and the gravy didn’t thicken up like it should have.
Next time, add more S&P or onion salt. Otherwise, good!
Absolutely positively the best pot roast I have ever made. Everyone went on and on about it. It is now a staple at our house.

I made this following the directions exactly. The mushrooms, carrots, celery, and onion made for a delicious variety of flavors and textures, and I served mine with mash potatoes adding to its heartiness. I was surprised to see the use of chicken broth instead of beef broth. Personally, I’m more a fan of beef broth or Lipton onion packet, but this variation was certainly a unique change from routine, and wasn’t too bad.

I've made this three times now and the first two times I used beef broth. This time I used chicken broth and have to agree with chef John on this. I like to serve it over horseradish mashed potatoes. Perfect!
This is better than the roast dish I have cooked all my life. Delicious!

Turned out great! Very tender, with that classic "pot roast" flavor. Mine definitely had to be on for 6 hours on high. Checked at 5 and it wasn't ready. Better to have dinner later than not as tasty! I've messed up slow cooker pot roasts before by not giving it enough time. 

I only had a 3-pound boneless bottom round of beef available, but it still worked out great with the same measurements otherwise. Got four nice servings out of that. 

My slow cooker is rather large, and the liquid didn't cover the meat completely. I just flipped it twice during cooking. I pulled it apart into chunks (not shreds!) after I turned off the slow cooker and let it cool for a bit before serving. 

If you like to have more of a gravy, you should either add more flour to the onion/mushroom mix before mixing in the chicken stock, or add a cornstarch slurry in the last half hour. 

I did have to skim quite a bit of fat off the top, but that was my mistake in using both oil and butter for the mushroom and onions. I usually do that to avoid the butter burning, but the mushrooms released enough liquid that it probably would have been fine.
i love this recipe! It's my go to for roasts. But instead of slow cooking i use my instant pot and cook it for 40 minutes of beef/stew setting, saves me some time.
I only had a 3lbs chuck roast , but kept the other ingredients the same. I also used only 1/2 Of the chicken broth, substituting red wine to make up the difference.

Made this for the first time last night. I found watching the video beforehand helpful. Recipe was easy to follow. I could not find the “7 bone” cut so I used a Chuck roast instead. Used a 3 1/2lb piece for the 4 of us and still had leftovers. I’ve tried many recipes in the past with 100’s of 5 star reviews only to be disappointed with the results. This was not the case here. Everyone loved it and would like to have it again so a copy of this will be going in my recipe keeper! Wonderful meal for those cold winter nights. TY Chef John!! I will take some time to look up more of your recipes.
I've made it twice. perfect every time!
I followed the recipe almost exactly. I used a seven bone chuck roast that was a little smaller than called for. It came out amazing. I will definitely make this again!
It's a bit more prep than just sticking everything in the pot, but the results are worth it!

EXCELLENT.
Used 1/2 chicken stock,1/2 vegetable stock
because thats what I had. A 2.5 lb boneless 
roast and extra carrots.
My family said it was the best pot roast that I have ever made, NO LEFTOVERS!!!
I used a boneless chuck roast, omitted celery. I used some red wine to deglaze the skillet after onions and mushrooms.I thickened up the sauce with some cornstarch to make gravy to pour over.
Delicious best ever !
Definitely a 5 star recipe! Used a 3 lb boneless rib and cooked on low 9 hrs. Used the drippings to make gravy at the end. Will use this recipe for years to come!

A little more arduous than simply throwing everything in the crock, but the extra steps make for a better tasting roast. BTW, I always sear the meat before crocking it; but not with the flour. Making the sauce this way gives a different level of flavor. I did choose however to switch out the butter for olive oil, a dietary preference. Short story... excellent!

Chef John thank you for this incredibly delicious recipe! It is the best roast that I and my family have ever tasted and is more than 5 stars in our opinion! I didn't have mushrooms on hand but it was still fabulous and I look forward to making it again with them. My 7 yr old who dislikes roast absolutely loved it. Also I enjoyed having leftover gravy which I was able to use in something else the next day. Fabulous :)

I made this for my daughter-in-laws birthday yesterday, there were 9 of us, everyone loved it! It is a great & easy way to make a full meal in one container, all you have to do is make the mashed potatoes to go with it. The meat fell apart and the gravy flavor was unbelievable! The only thing I'll do different next time is to put more carrots and celery in the bottom. This is my go to way to roast from now on! Thank you Chef John!

I made this recipe today with a 3 pound boneless chuck roast. it was delicious! I cooked it 1 hour on high, then changed it to low for 4 hours. The meat falls apart and is very tasty. I thought it odd to use chicken broth in a beef recipe, but it worked great. I love carrots so I added a couple extra and cut them in about 3 inch chunks so they wouldn't get mushy. I Also used dried thyme and rosemary. This recipe is a keeper for me.
Awesome!!!!

I used tri-tip beef cut into 1-inch cubes and white rice flour to make it gluten-free. I also increased the veggies to include 1 small sweet potato and 1/3 of a yuca root. I also used 4 small cloves of garlic, most of a red onion, and 6-8 baby bell portabella mushrooms. I added a bit more chicken broth after putting it all together into the crockpot. We'll see how it is after 5-6 hours. So far it smells wonderful so I think it will be great! I will serve the meat and vegetables over herbed brown rice.

Great! In the past, I've always skipped browning the roast. So much better with browning, and I love the addition of the tomato paste! (I don't care for thyme or rosemary, so I omitted those this time and added a little parsley...but that's just a preference.)

This is the second time I've made this recipe. I was tired of the standard "onion soup mix" roast. This was delicious! Searing the roast with salt, pepper and flour first made the roast caramelize during cooking. It was delicious. I didn't have chicken broth this time, so I'm using beef broth and substituting 1/2 c. red wine for part of the broth. We're looking forward to the results!
excellent

Another winning recipe from Chef John! You know it's good when the bf requests pot roast...and then he requests to have it again within the next week! This is really a fantastic full-meal, crock pot recipe and I can't wait to use it mid-summer when I seem to NEVER want to turn the oven on! 

I made some tweaks based on preferences and what I had on hand. My roast was boneless because that is what I could easily get, and I seasoned the roast with both onion & garlic powder prior to searing. I added about 3/4 cup red wine and 2 tbsp of worcestershire sauce for added flavor (went easy on salting the roast itself since both of these ingredients were adding salt). I also used low-sodium beef broth since that's what I had. Used dried herbs in place of fresh (1 tsp rosemary, 2 tsp thyme). I let it cook a full 6 hours on high and the roast was fall-apart tender. To finish it up, I thickened the jus with a flour slurry on the stove and served it with Chef John's perfect mashed potatoes and some roasted string beans. Delish!
I have made this a few times and Love it

OMG! Excellent. I usually will not change a recipe the first time I make it, but I had no chicken broth, so I used beef broth. I also had no fresh mushrooms, so used canned. This was fantastic. This will be my go to pot roast recipe from now on. Can't wait to see how yummy it will be with fresh mushrooms!
Awesome recipe!!
Was very good, made it for the NFL Draft 2020
BEST Pot Roast Recipe Ever. Worth all the work and wait!
Absolutely delicious. Tender as can be. Stayed with the recipe.
We loved it. I used more carrots. stock, rosemary, and thyme than called for. Mainly because I had more on hand. But this was a great feast! Thanks Chef John!
Best pot roast I've ever had. Only complaint I got was there wasn't enough vegetables. Easily remedied for next time.

WOW! This is the best pot roast I’ve ever had. I pretty much followed the recipe but forgot the butter. I didn’t have celery so I included potatoes and I used canned mushrooms. Really enjoyed this meal.

This recipe was so easy to follow. I made it with a boneless roast added more celery and carrots. The other change i did which my family loved. I took a pound of mushrooms and instead of cooking them like the recipe states i dumped them on top of the roast put the top on the crockpot and forgot about it! It was awesome!
So easy to follow and make. My family ate it like there was no tomorrow. Searing, though, is the key - and all sides!

Chef John, Lord of the Roast, I’ve been making this for 4 years now off of your recipe and am just now getting around to reviewing. Only thing I do different is cut celery/carrots up and put them in slow cooker while you’re browning the roast. That way, instead of setting aside the roast when it’s done browning (in my cluttered bachelor kitchen where counter space is limited), I set it straight in the crockpot on the veggies. Regardless if this effects the resting process, it’s not bad enough to make me want to organize my kitchen.
I added mini potatoes , and some coconut chicken lime broth OMG so good.. I also added some sazon ( culantro/ achote) for more flavor.. so good...

This is the best recipe for Pot Roast! I already had all the ingredients I needed and it was so simple. We had friends over for dinner and they loved it. I made mash potatoes to go with it. I will definitely make it again.
very good...
Only changes were as per other reviews and used beef broth instead of chicken broth. It was very tender and well received by our guests.

Wonderful! Very flavorful and tender....only changes that I made, no flour when searing, used one cup red wine and only 1 1/2 cup stock .... at the end of cooking added a touch of heavy cream and thickened a bit with cornstarch. Loved by all served with polenta and great leftovers the next day!

I made this recipe on a cold day in Chicago! It was perfect. The only additions I made were more veggies as we are a veggie family. The only thing was ( maybe I'm slow in the kitchen,) It took me 45 min. to prep by the time I cleaned, cut. spanked and braised. It was well worth it.
Used bison chuck roast. Delicious!
was very good, the kids loved it
It was very good, with a nice rich gravy. It was a bit more like a stew, than what I expected.

I am a transplanted Brit and have tried making the All-American Pot Roast several times but never been pleased with the result. Then I made Chef John's recipe. Wow! It was awesome. I had a 3lb chuck roast and cooked it for 8 hours on low. It was perfect. I substituted 1 cup of red wine for 1 cup of the beef broth but otherwise followed the recipe. My husband, also a Brit, pronounced it utterly delicious! I will make it again for the family.
Takes a bit of prep (which I wasn't really prepared for at 6am, before work) but this recipe tastes absolutely amazing and the whole family loved it!

I made this according to instructions (ok, I added more mushrooms). We thought this was a great main dish and the accompanying vegetable went well with it. The 6 hours of braising in the slow cooker resulted in a tender pot roast. Chef John emphasizes the initial sear to the meat which seals it for the long braising process. Always nice to see Chef John's recipes-a great resource.
made it as the recipe states. just perfect!
This was excellent. Took a bit of preparation, but worth it. I could have included more vegetables than i did.
Always amazing. It take a little time the first time to prep, but I've done it three times now. Get everything out. You can cut most of the veggies while the meat is browning. Family loves it!

We had a wild bear roast in the deep freeze for a while, and I finally got the courage to make something with it. This recipe was easy and it turned out so tender and delicious. I added a bit of worchestershire sause and used left over venison gravy from an earlier crockpot meal that turned out so great, I saved the gravy to use on noodles. But ended up substituting the chicken stock with the left over gravy. Also added baby protabello mushrooms the recipe. I bet even with a beef roast, any of my additions would make it special.
No changes and it was great.

I followed the recipe except for the rosemary as my husband doesn’t like it, and some extra vegetable bullion. It turned out great, and 2 days later, after leftovers sat in the fridge, I heated it in the oven and it might have been even better. Served it with mashed potatoes to friends who I wanted to visit with, instead of working in the kitchen. Give this one a shot as written, folks!

Made in a stock pot, then baked at 250 for about 5 hours. Meat was perfectly cooked and fell apart. I also used beef broth, added a lot more of all seasonings (garlic, rosemary, and thyme!) I like these types of meals to be hearty and flavorful and these changes accomplished that! It was a delicious dish!

Made in a stock pot, then baked at 250 for about 5 hours. Meat was perfectly cooked and fell apart. I also used beef broth, added a lot more of all seasonings (garlic, rosemary, and thyme!) I like these types of meals to be hearty and flavorful and these changes accomplished that! It was a delicious dish!
I think next time I make this I will leave out the tomato paste and put in more carrots.
